TIL that in 2006, teenage fans of a popular Portuguese soap opera began experiencing the physical symptoms of a fictional disease that was introduced to the characters on the show. The "outbreak" spread to over 300 people. It is considered an example of mass hysteria.

WRITING.TITLE: TIL that in 2004, a 19m tall sculpture of Jesus, named "King of Kings", was erected in Ohio. It was the 7th tallest statue in the United States at the time. In 2010, it was struck by lightning and was destroyed by the subsequent fire.

TIL that the concept of an atomic bomb was introduced in a novel by HG Wells in 1914. Eighteen years after its publication, the physicist Le Szilrd read the book, was inspired, and two years later filed a patent on the idea of a neutron chain reaction, leading eventually to atomic bomb technology.

TIL that during the 1983 US Open, an errant serve from Stefan Edberg struck a linesman directly on the groin. The linesman fell backward, striking his head, and fell unconscious. He died in hospital five days later.
TIL that it is estimated that the number of rats in New York City may be as high as 32 million. That's four rats per person.

WRITING.TITLE: TIL that one of the most famous pubs in Australia is the Young and Jackson Hotel. It is famous for its portrait "Chloe" of a very nude 19 years old girl, which hangs over one of the bars. It was considered scandalous at the time, but still hangs there.

TIL that Puccini's 1910 opera, "La fanciulla del West", is set in the American old west, featuring a bandit, a sherriff and a "bartender at the Polka saloon". Some consider it the first "Spaghetti Western".

TIL that when the Space Shuttle Challenger exploded in 1986, this joke spread quickly around the world: "Q: What does NASA stand for? A: Need Another Seven Astronauts." This was before widespread use of the internet. The joke spread literally by word of mouth.

WRITING.TITLE: TIL that before the world wibe web, internet users had multiplayer role-playing online games called MUSHs. This stands for Multi User Shared Hallucination. These games were played via the unix command line, i.e via text, no graphics, but were enourmosly popular amongst college students at the time.

I recommend [this article](http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/features/fearless-matriarch-of-resistance/story-e6frg6z6-1226111207166). VERY late in life (age 88 by my reckoning) she said she wanted to die in London and moved to an expensive hotel in Piccadilly. She ran out of money, though, but the hotel didn't want to kick her out. Prince Charles started footing the bill. She had her own stool at the hotel bar, where during her nineties she would have at least 6 gin and tonics a day. Good for her, I say. She died in 2011 at age 98.
And I don't wanna talk to a scientist.

WRITING.TITLE: TIL that in ancient Rome, one of the most common cooking ingredients was called "laser", from the silphium plant. It does not exist today: it was so delicious that it was harvested to extinction from its natural habitat in what is now Libya. We think that it probably tasted something like garlic.

TIL that Brazilians' enthusiasm for the internet led to the decline of fotolog.net and google's now sort of defunct orkut.net. There were so many Brazilians on these sites that they stifled anyone else's contributions. It's called the "Brazilian internet phenomenon".

WRITING.TITLE: TIL the Sentinalese people have lived on an isolated island in the Indian Ocean for an estimated 60,000 years. They reject all contact with outsiders and are the last group of people who have had virtually no contact with the modern world.
